questions.question_text:
Your company implements an Agile development methodology.
You plan to implement retrospectives at the end of each sprint.
Which three questions should you include? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

comments.content:
Correct , CDE
During the Sprint Retrospective, the team discusses:

What went well in the Sprint
What could be improved
What will we commit to improve in the next Sprint
https://www.scrum.org/resources/what-is-a-sprint-retrospective

yea instead of who did this? who slacked? who screwed up?
retro and reflection, not finger pointing session

discussion.content: Correction C,D,E should be correct answers

C. What could have gone better?
D. What went well?
E. What should we try next?

Selected Answer: CDE
C,D,E are correct. In a Project, stop pointing fingers to team members. So the Who? is a big NO. You need the WHAT!!!

Selected Answer: CDE
Blame-free retrospectives & Just a culture.

CDE

Selected Answer: CDE
C. What could have gone better?
D. What went well?
E. What should we try next?

Selected Answer: CDE
C,D and E

Selected Answer: CDE
It is clearly stated in the link provided by SriLen
https://www.scrum.org/resources/what-is-a-sprint-retrospective

Selected Answer: CD
Not Who else What

Retrospective NEVER focus on individuals, they always focus on the WHAT. What went well, what could have been done better, what do we want to try next, what do we want to do less, what do we want to stop doing or avoid doing and so on. So A annd B are automatically excluded, leaving C,D,E.

Selected Answer: CDE
CDE is the right Answer for sure.
During the Sprint Retrospective, the team discusses:

What went well in the Sprint
What could be improved
What will we commit to improve in the next Sprint

https://www.scrum.org/resources/what-is-a-sprint-retrospective

Selected Answer: CDE
CDE for sure

It's the process that we are looking at and not the individuals
its "WHAT" rather than "WHO" in Agile...

Selected Answer: CDE
CDE are correct.

Selected Answer: CDE
in the retrospective the questions are what? not who?

Selected Answer: CDE
CDE is the proper one

Selected Answer: CDE
not about who

Selected Answer: CDE
I'm sure that CDE are correct ones.

Selected Answer: CDE
CDE it should be. Agenda is to understand What not Who which might end up as a blame on someone.
Answer is CDE

Selected Answer: CDE
Not who, but what
Any day CDE
What, What, What. Not Who, Who, Who.

C. What could have gone better?
D. What went well?
E. What should we try next?
CDE Is correct
CDE, because the focus of the analysis resides in the process not in persons.
CDE correct

During the Sprint Retrospective, the team discusses:

What went well in the Sprint
What could be improved
What will we commit to improve in the next Sprint

https://www.scrum.org/resources/what-is-a-sprint-retrospective
CDE is the ANSWER
Obviously its CDE
Common sense really

"B. Who should have performed better?"
WTF, this type of question will demoralize that person and the team as a whole.

we don't use 'Who' in the retro.
CDE
C,D and E Varified

comments.content: Always a good thing to have a healthy discussion

discussion.content: I think that some of these are intentionally giving the wrong answers just to get people to sign up so they can "discuss". This is clearly C, D, E.
Correct answer should be C, D, E

During the Sprint Retrospective, the team discusses:

 What went well in the Sprint
 What could be improved
 What will we commit to improve in the next Sprint
https://www.scrum.org/resources/what-is-a-sprint-retrospective

During the Sprint Retrospective, the team discusses:

What went well in the Sprint
What could be improved
What will we commit to improve in the next Sprint

Source scrum.org : https://www.scrum.org/resources/what-is-a-sprint-retrospective
answer should be CDE
C, D, E should be correct answers. We focus on WHAT, not WHO

CDE
Who ? is for Daily Standup 
What ? is Retrospective

CDE - what questions
https://www.scrum.org/resources/what-is-a-sprint-retrospective
Answers should be C, D and E
CDE, this is called a blameless retrospective

comments.content: These are the questions for a daily standup scrum meeting, not a retrospective...

discussion.content:
veryone participates, each team member answers the three Scrum questions:
What have I accomplished since the most recent Scrum?
What will I accomplish before the next Scrum?
What blocking issues or impediments might affect my wor
B,C,D should be correct answers

questions.question_text:
You are integrating an Azure Boards project and a GitHub repository.

You need to authenticate Azure Boards to GitHub.

Which two authentication methods can you use? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
DE is the answer.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/boards/github/connect-to-github?view=azure-devops#authentication-options
The following authentication options are supported based on the GitHub platform you want to connect to.
GitHub.com
- GitHub.com user account (Recommended)
- Personal access token (PAT)

Selected Answer: DE
D. GitHub user credentials
E. a personal access token (PAT)

Selected Answer: DE
While I'd choose d and e, it is good to note that the Github credentials are never stored in Azure directly.

Selected Answer: DE
agreew ith answer

Selected Answer: DE
I believe it's correct.

E. A PAT

D. GitHub User Creds
https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-devops-docs/blob/main/docs/boards/github/connect-to-github.md

choices.C: Microsoft Azure Active Directory (Azure AD), part of Microsoft Entra

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is the answer.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/boards/github/link-to-from-github?view=azure-devops#use-ab-mention-to-link-from-github-to-azure-boards-work-items
From a GitHub commit, pull request or issue, use the following syntax to create a link to your Azure Boards work item. Enter the AB#ID within the text of a commit message. Or, for a pull request or issue, enter the AB#ID within the title or description (not a comment).
AB# so answer is B

Selected Answer: B
Azure Boards Integration: When GitHub and Azure Boards are integrated, Azure Boards recognizes keywords within commit messages. The format AB# followed by the work item ID (e.g., AB#715) triggers an automatic update in the linked work item within Azure Boards.

Selected Answer: B
AB# is fot github repositories integrated with azure boards

Answer is B.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/boards/github/link-to-from-github?view=azure-devops

Selected Answer: B
Answer is correct:

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/boards/github/link-to-from-github?view=azure-devops

comments.content: when you try to refer it in devops, the answer is D, but the question is github, so, should be B

discussion.content: Correct Answer is : D

Selected Answer: D
I believe its D.

You just need to reference the ID of the issue next to the "#" sign.

choices.A: the URL of the work item

questions.question_text:
You have a GitHub repository that is integrated with Azure Boards. Azure Boards has a work item that has the number 715.

You need to ensure that when you commit source code in GitHub, the work item is updated automatically.

What should you include in the commit comments?

You are creating a dashboard in Azure Boards.

You need to visualize the time from when work starts on a work item until the work item is closed.

Which type of widget should you use?

discussion.content:
STARTED- CYCLE TIME
CREATED - LEAD TIME

Selected Answer: A
A. cycle time

Selected Answer: A
agree with A

Selected Answer: A
I thought the answer was Lead time at first but it is cycle time or A. The lead time starts when the work item is created. The cycle time starts when the work is started on the work item. The answer is A, Cycle Time.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/report/dashboards/cycle-time-and-lead-time?view=vsts - also found in this Examtopics Question 1 Topic 1.

Selected Answer: A
A is the answer.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/report/dashboards/cycle-time-and-lead-time?view=azure-devops
Both lead time and cycle time widgets are useful to teams. They both indicate how long it takes for work to flow through their development pipeline. Lead time measures the total time elapsed from the creation of work items to their completion. Cycle time measures the time it takes for your team to complete work items once they begin actively working on them.

Selected Answer: A
Bicycle.
Correct Answer : A

questions.question_text:
You manage a project by using Azure Boards. You manage the project code by using GitHub.

You have three work items that have IDs of 456, 457, and 458.

You need to create a pull request that will be linked to all the work items. The solution must set the state of work item 456 to done.

What should you add to the commit message?

comments.content: yeah, should be Fixes AB#456, AB#457, AB#458

discussion.content:
Correct answer should be using AB#ID instead.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/boards/github/link-to-from-github?view=azure-devops#use-ab-mention-to-link-from-github-to-azure-boards-work-items
From a GitHub commit, pull request or issue, use the following syntax to create a link to your Azure Boards work item. Enter the AB#ID within the text of a commit message. Or, for a pull request or issue, enter the AB#ID within the title or description (not a comment).

Selected Answer: D
To create a pull request that will be linked to multiple Azure Boards work items and set the state of one of the work items to "Done," you should use the correct syntax in the commit message. The syntax should include the "AB#" prefix for Azure Boards work items and the "Fixes" keyword to automatically update the state of the work item.

Selected Answer: B
Can anyone update the bad B option to the correct option text?

Selected Answer: B
B. Fixes #AB456, #AB457, #AB458

you need: Fixes + AB# in Github

Selected Answer: B
Ignore my earlier comment, answer is correct
Fixes AB#123, AB#124, AB#125 will complete first item and will create link for all three.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/boards/github/link-to-from-github?view=azure-devops

It should be like like Fixes AB#123, Fixes AB#124, Fixes AB#125. Need to have Fixes before all items to complete. Otherwise it will create only links.

Fixes AB#123, AB#124, AB#125 will only complete only first item and will create link for all three.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/boards/github/link-to-from-github?view=azure-devops

Selected Answer: B
Voted B: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/boards/github/link-to-from-github?view=azure-devops

Fixes AB#123, AB#124, and AB#126 Links to Azure Boards work items 123, 124, and 126. Transitions only the first item, 123 to the Resolved workflow state category or, if none is defined, then the Completed workflow state category.

Selected Answer: B
Definitely B. We are accessing Azure Boards work items from Github. You must affix "AB" before the # when referencing Azure Boards from Github

Selected Answer: A
For Issue, use #<Number>
For Work Item, use AB#<Number>
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/boards/github/link-to-from-github?view=azure-devops
Maybe there's a typo in the question so I would choose option A

comments.content: The AB designation is not a Issue vs Work Item thing. Using AB is how you denote Azure Board work items from within Github. Since the problem presents us having a GitHub project, so we use #AB123 to denote a Azure Boards work item. Its B

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Solution is B

Selected Answer: B

From a GitHub commit, pull request or issue, use the following syntax to create a link to your Azure Boards work item. Enter the AB#ID within the text of a commit message. Or, for a pull request or issue, enter the AB#ID within the title or description (not a comment).

Therefore, the solution is "B"

discussion.content:
gpt said:
To create a pull request that will be linked to all the work items and set the state of work item 456 to "done," you should use the commit message option:

A. Fixes #456, #457, #458

This format with the "Fixes" keyword and the work item IDs referenced will automatically link the pull request to the associated work items in Azure Boards. Additionally, it will set the state of work item 456 to "done" when the pull request is completed.

So the correct commit message would be:
"Fixes #456, #457, #458"

Selected Answer: A
I go with A

Selected Answer: A
Similar to a previous question, just re-worded.

To create a pull request in GitHub that is linked to multiple work items and sets the state of work item 456 to "Done" in Azure Boards, you can use the following syntax in your commit message:

Fixes #456, #457, #458

Your commit message here

In this case, the keyword "Fixes" is used to indicate that the commit addresses and resolves the work items. By specifying the work item IDs separated by commas after the keyword, you link the pull request to those work items in Azure Boards.

For example, your commit message could be:

Fixes #456, #457, #458 - Implemented new feature X
When you create the pull request, it will be automatically linked to the three work items. Additionally, work item 456 will have its state updated to "Done" based on the commit activity.
Correct Answer : A

Selected Answer: A
Tested and the correct answer is A.

We just need to reference the workitems using "#ID".
To close a workitem we can use the syntax "Fixes #ID". 
Multiple workitems can be referenced being divided by a ",".
